A 35-year-old male reports progressive weakness affecting his proximal limbs, especially difficulty climbing stairs and rising from a seated position, which has developed over the last three years. He also describes intermittent dysphagia and mild dysarthria that have worsened recently. The patient notes frequent muscle twitching in his arms and legs and occasional hand tremors. He has a history of gynecomastia and reduced libido, with no significant past medical history. Neurological examination reveals decreased muscle bulk in the hands and tongue fasciculations, with diminished deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. Laboratory studies show mildly elevated serum creatine kinase and normal hormone levels except for slightly reduced testosterone. Electromyography demonstrates chronic neurogenic changes predominantly affecting bulbar and limb muscles. Genetic analysis identifies an expanded CAG repeat in the androgen receptor gene, confirming spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy, X-linked 1.
